t: Job 28
A Hymn to Wisdom
Surely*pn there is a mine for silver and*ln a place where gold is refined.
Iron*ln is taken from the ground, and*ln copper is smelted from ore.
A*ln miner puts an end to the darkness; he*ln probes the deepest recesses for*ln ore in the gloomy darkness.
He*ln cuts a shaft far from human habitation, in*ln places unknown to those who walk above ground. Suspended*ln far away from people, the*ln miners swing back and forth.
Food*ln may come from the earth, but*ln below the surface the earth is transformed as by fire.
Its*ln rocks are a source of lapis lazuli, containing*ln flecks of gold.
No*ln bird of prey knows that path; no*ln falcon’s eye has seen it.
Proud*ln beasts have never walked on it; no*ln lion has ever prowled over it.
The*ln miner uses a flint tool and*ln turns up ore from the root of the mountains.
He*ln cuts out channels in the rocks, and*ln his eyes spot every treasure.
He*ln dams up the streams from flowing so*ln that he may bring to light what is hidden.
But*pn where can wisdom be found, and*ln where is understanding located?
No*ln one can know its value, since*ln it cannot be found in the land of the living.
The*ln ocean depths say, “It’s not in me,” while*ln the sea declares, “I don’t have it.”
Gold*ln cannot be exchanged for it, and*ln silver cannot be weighed out for its price.
Wisdom*ln cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir, in*ln precious onyx or lapis lazuli.
Gold*ln and glass do not compare with it, and*ln articles of fine gold cannot be exchanged for it.
Coral*ln and quartz are not worth mentioning. The*ln price of wisdom is beyond pearls.
Topaz*ln from Cush cannot compare with it, and*ln it cannot be valued in pure gold.
Where*pn then does wisdom come from, and*ln where is understanding located?
It*ln is hidden from the eyes of every living thing and*ln concealed from the birds of the sky.
Abaddon*ln and Death say, “We*ln have heard news of it with our ears.”
But*ln God understands the way to wisdom, and*ln he knows its location.
For*ln he looks to the ends of the earth and*ln sees everything under the heavens.
When*ln God fixed the weight of the wind and*ln distributed the water by measure,
when*ln he established a limit for the rain and*ln a path for the lightning,
he*ln considered wisdom and evaluated it; he*ln established it and examined it.
He*ln said to mankind, “The*ln fear of the Lord—that is wisdom. And*ln to turn from evil is understanding.”
